Clinic Seeks Flu Vaccine
For Students, Employees
Vaccine for Asiatic Flu shots
is being sought by the Student
Health Service to innoculate the
students and employees which it
serves, Dr. Frank Smith, Director
of the Student Health Service
revealed.
The Health Service has requested vaccine but as yet has
no assurance if they will receive
the vaccine nor when they would
receive it. If the vaccine does
arrive, the Health Service will
notify the student body. Dr.
Smith requests that students refrain from coming to the clinic
to inquire about the shots as

Priority Established
The machinery for innoculating the students has not yet been
fully set up, but the shots will
probably be given during the
regular clinic hours, 10-1, and
2-5. Priority for shots will follow
the recommendations of the
American Medical Association
and the Public Health Service.
Health Service personnel and
food handlers will be innoculated
first, then the maintenance
workers, undergraduates and
graduate students. The faculty

1882, just six years after Johns Hopkins opened its
doors as the nation's first university, was the year that the
school, located then in the heart of Baltimore, innovated
the gridiron sport in a contest against the U. S. Naval
Academy.
In 1948, Hopkins won the first official Mason-Dixon
Conference football title, finished the season with a 7-1
mark, and turned down an invitation to the Tangerine
Bowl game.
Last year saw the Blue Jays emulate their 1948 feat
by again copping the M-D grid Championship.
Snow was still on the ground when the Jay stickmen
began preparations for their bid for the National Intercollegiate Lacrosse Championship.
The Blue Jays climaxed their seventy-fifth season by
taking the Cyrus C. Miller trophy, emblematic of the "A"
division championship, and the Wingate trophy, signifying
the national intercollegiate lacrosse championship.
Hopkins' 11-11 tie with the Mt. Washington Lacrosse
Club to make them co-open lacrosse champions was anticlimatic.
Frisbee!
However, this is all ancient history now. A new
sport has Manifestpd itself on the Blue Jay athletic horizon. Frisbee!
Originally employing beer trays, the game is rumored
to have been played by the Indians when Lief Ericson discovered America.
A nine and a quarter inch in diameter plastic discus
called a "Pluto Platter" has replaced the beer tray of
yesteryear. On the Princeton University campus, frisbee
is included in the intramural athletic program.
Frisbee Tournament
Commenting on the possibility of frisbee becoming an
intramural sport at the Hopkins, the president of the
Board of Intramural Athletics, Stu Viess, said, "If there's
enough interest among the independents and fraternities
to warrant a frisbee tournament, the Board of Intramural
Athletics will certainly go along- with the interest of the
students."
With wrestling now missing from the Blue Jays'
athletic program, it may not be too long until Hopkins
fields a frisbee squad. All interested students are asked
to indicate their desire by dropping a note in box 1230
in the Gilman post office.

single wing is that almost all
boys who play high school or

"T," and, therefore, when they
graduate to the varsity, they
have to learn a whole new system of plays, blocking assignments, etc.

no athletic scholarships and
minimized recruiting generally
results in the Jays being outmanned and out-weighed by

formation is needed that can
compensate, at least in part, for
these deficiencies.

play, the quick opener, requires

a heavy line and tremendous
speed both in the backfield and
in the forward wall, qualities
which Hopkins teams in past
years have found difficult to
achieve.
The single-wing, on the other
hand, requires good ball-handling and smart line play, but
large, powerful linemen and
tremendous backfield speed are
not foremost in importance, the
"power" being provided by double and triple teaming rather
than "beef."
